Appendix B Proofs for Security Results

We hereby give formal arguments showing that our integration of XNoise and SecAgg (denoted by π𝜋\pi and specified in section 3.3), preserves privacy against malicious adversaries. As is standard, we consider only computationally-bounded adversarial parties, namely those whose strategies can be described by some probabilistic polynomial-time (PPT) algorithm M𝑀M. The proof will be performed in the so-called ‘Random Oracle’ model (Bellare and Rogaway, 1993). We assume that a common random oracle O𝑂O is available to all the parties, who can each make arbitrarily many oracle queries to O𝑂O during the course of their execution. In its primary form, given input x𝑥x and bit length l𝑙l, O𝑂O outputs a binary string of length l𝑙l, O​(x)𝑂𝑥O(x), such that i) each O​(x)𝑂𝑥O(x) is uniformly random and independent, and that ii) repeated queries on the same x𝑥x and l𝑙l give the same result. Additionally, given input x𝑥x, bit length l𝑙l, vector length V𝑉V and distribution χ𝜒\chi, O𝑂O outputs a list of L𝐿L bit strings of length l𝑙l, Oχ​(x)subscript𝑂𝜒𝑥O_{\chi}(x), such that i) all the bit strings of Oχ​(x)subscript𝑂𝜒𝑥O_{\chi}(x) follow the same distribution χ𝜒\chi and are mutually independent and all Oχ​(x)subscript𝑂𝜒𝑥O_{\chi}(x)’s are mutually independent, and repeated queries on the same x𝑥x, l𝑙l, V𝑉V, and χ𝜒\chi give the same result. We assume that all honest parties will substitute all PRG calls and noise sampling with calls to O𝑂O.

Denote with 𝚫U′={𝚫u}u∈U′subscript𝚫superscript𝑈′subscriptsubscript𝚫𝑢𝑢superscript𝑈′\bm{\Delta}_{U^{\prime}}=\{\bm{\Delta}_{u}\}_{u\in U^{\prime}} and gU′={gu,k}u∈U′,k∈[0,T]subscript𝑔superscript𝑈′subscriptsubscript𝑔𝑢𝑘formulae-sequence𝑢superscript𝑈′𝑘0𝑇g_{U^{\prime}}=\{g_{u,k}\}_{u\in U^{\prime},k\in[0,T]} the inputs of any subset of users U′⊆Usuperscript𝑈′𝑈U^{\prime}\subseteq U. For fixed η𝜂\eta, t𝑡t, U𝑈U, T𝑇T, and a set C𝐶C of corrupted parties, we let MCsubscript𝑀𝐶M_{C} indicate the polynomial-time algorithm that denotes the ‘next-message’ function of parties in C𝐶C. We allow MCsubscript𝑀𝐶M_{C} to dynamically choose which users to abort in each round, rather than the aborts being statically fixed beforehand.

The following lemma shows that the joint view of colluding corrupt parties in a real execution of π𝜋\pi can be simulated by SIM given only an (overly perturbed) sum of a (dynamically chosen) subset of at least δ𝛿\delta honest users’ input vectors and some set of seeds used in noise addition by them, meaning intuitively that the adversary can learn ‘nothing more’ than these two pieces of information. Note that we allow SIM to make a single query to an ideal functionality Ideal that is defined with appropriately chosen δ𝛿\delta as follows

Ideal𝚫U∖C,gU∖Cδ​(L)={∑u∈L𝚫~u,{gu,k}u∈L,|U∖L|+1−|C∩U|≤k≤T,if ​L⊆(U∖C)​ and ​|L|≥δ,⟂,otherwise,subscriptsuperscriptIdeal𝛿subscript𝚫𝑈𝐶subscript𝑔𝑈𝐶𝐿casessubscript𝑢𝐿subscript~𝚫𝑢subscriptsubscript𝑔𝑢𝑘formulae-sequence𝑢𝐿𝑈𝐿1𝐶𝑈𝑘𝑇otherwiseif 𝐿𝑈𝐶 and 𝐿𝛿otherwiseperpendicular-tootherwiseotherwise\displaystyle\textrm{{Ideal}}^{\delta}_{\bm{\Delta}_{U\setminus C},g_{U\setminus C}}(L)=\begin{cases}\sum_{u\in L}\tilde{\bm{\Delta}}_{u},\{g_{u,k}\}_{u\in L,\lvert U\setminus L\rvert+1-\lvert C\cap U\rvert\leq k\leq T},\\ \hfill\textrm{if \ }L\subseteq(U\setminus C)\textrm{\ and \ }\lvert L\rvert\geq\delta,\\ \perp,\hfill\textrm{otherwise},\end{cases}

where L𝐿L can be chosen dynamically by SIM at run time.

Lemma 0.

There exists a PPT simulator SIM such that for all η𝜂\eta, t𝑡t, U𝑈U, T𝑇T, C⊆U∪{S}𝐶𝑈𝑆C\subseteq U\cup\{S\}, 𝚫U∖Csubscript𝚫𝑈𝐶\bm{\Delta}_{U\setminus C} and gU∖Csubscript𝑔𝑈𝐶g_{U\setminus C}. If 2t>|U|+|C∩U|2t>\lvert U\rvert+\lvert C\cap U\lvert , the output of SIM is computationally indistinguishable from the output of REALπ,Cη,t,U,TsubscriptsuperscriptabsentηtUTπC{}^{\eta,t,U,T}_{\pi,C}:

REALπ,Cη,t,U,T​(MC,𝚫U∖C,gU∖C)≈cSIMCη,t,U,T,Ideal𝚫U∖C,gU∖Cδ​(MC),subscript𝑐subscriptsuperscriptREAL𝜂𝑡𝑈𝑇𝜋𝐶subscript𝑀𝐶subscript𝚫𝑈𝐶subscript𝑔𝑈𝐶superscriptsubscriptSIM𝐶𝜂𝑡𝑈𝑇subscriptsuperscriptIdeal𝛿subscript𝚫𝑈𝐶subscript𝑔𝑈𝐶subscript𝑀𝐶\textrm{{REAL}}^{\eta,t,U,T}_{\pi,C}(M_{C},\bm{\Delta}_{U\setminus C},g_{U\setminus C})\approx_{c}\textrm{{SIM}}_{C}^{\eta,t,U,T,\textrm{{Ideal}}^{\delta}_{\bm{\Delta}_{U\setminus C},g_{U\setminus C}}}(M_{C}),

where δ=t−|C∩U|\delta=t-\lvert C\cap U\lvert.

Proof.

We prove the theorem by a standard hybrid argument. We will define a simulator SIM through a series of (polynomially many) subsequent modifications to the real execution REAL, so that the views of MCsubscript𝑀𝐶M_{C} in any two subsequent executions are computationally indistinguishable.

  1. Hyb1

    This random variable is distributed exactly as the view of MCsubscript𝑀𝐶M_{C} is REAL, the joint view of the parties C𝐶C in a real execution of the protocol.

  2. Hyb2

    In this hybrid, SIM has access to all the inputs of honest parties 𝚫U∖Csubscript𝚫𝑈𝐶\bm{\Delta}_{U\setminus C}, and gU∖Csubscript𝑔𝑈𝐶g_{U\setminus C}, and runs the full protocol with MCsubscript𝑀𝐶M_{C}, which includes simulating the random oracle ‘on the fly’ (using a dynamically generated table), the PKI, and the rest of the Setup phase. The view of the adversary here is the same as the previous one.

  3. Hyb3

    In this hybrid, SIM replaces the run of SecAgg with the ideal simulation of SecAgg as specified in the original paper.444See the proof of Theorem A.2 in the full paper of SecAgg (Bonawitz et al., 2017b). As established in the proof there, this hybrid is computationally indistinguishable from the previous one (on condition that 2​t>|U|+|C∩U|2𝑡𝑈𝐶𝑈2t>\lvert U\rvert+\lvert C\cap U\rvert), and differs from it only in polynomially many modifications as follows:

    • •

      SIM aborts if MCsubscript𝑀𝐶M_{C} provides any of the honest parties u𝑢u (in AdvertiseKey) with a correct signature w.r.t. an honest v𝑣v’s public key, on (cvP​K∥svP​K)conditionalsuperscriptsubscript𝑐𝑣𝑃𝐾superscriptsubscript𝑠𝑣𝑃𝐾(c_{v}^{PK}\|s_{v}^{PK}) different from those sent by v𝑣v.

    • •

      For any pair of honest users u𝑢u, v𝑣v, SIM encrypts the messages among them (in ShareKeys, before being given to MCsubscript𝑀𝐶M_{C}) and decrypts them (in Unmasking, after MCsubscript𝑀𝐶M_{C} has delivered them) using a uniformly random key (as opposed to the one obtained through the key agreement KA.agree (cuS​K,cvP​K)superscriptsubscript𝑐𝑢𝑆𝐾superscriptsubscript𝑐𝑣𝑃𝐾(c_{u}^{SK},c_{v}^{PK})).

    • •

      SIM additionally aborts if MCsubscript𝑀𝐶M_{C} succeeds to deliver, in ShareKeys, a message to an honest client u𝑢u on behalf of another honest client v𝑣v, such that i) the message is different from the message SIM had given MCsubscript𝑀𝐶M_{C} in ShareKeys, and ii) the message does not cause the decryption algorithm to fail.

    • •

      SIM substitutes all the encrypted shares sent between parties of honest users with encryptions of 00. (It still returns the ‘real’ shares in Round Unmasking as it did before).

    • •

      SIM aborts if MCsubscript𝑀𝐶M_{C} provides any of the honest parties (in ConsistencyCheck) with a signature on a set which correctly verifies w.r.t. the public key of an honest party, but the honest client never produced a signature on that set.

    • •

      SIM aborts if MCsubscript𝑀𝐶M_{C} queries the random oracle/PRG on input busubscript𝑏𝑢b_{u} for some honest user u𝑢u (i.e., the value sampled by SIM on behalf of u𝑢u in ShareKeys) either i) before the adversary received the responses from the honest users in Unmasking or ii) after such responses have been received, but u∉Q𝑢𝑄u\notin Q.555We define Q⊆U𝑄𝑈Q\subseteq U as the only set such that there exists an honest user which received the set Q in ConsistencyCheck and later received at least t𝑡t valid signatures on it in Unmasking; or empty set if no such Q𝑄Q exists.

    • •

      SIM aborts if MCsubscript𝑀𝐶M_{C} queries the random oracle/PRG on input su,vsubscript𝑠𝑢𝑣s_{u,v} for some honest users u𝑢u, v𝑣v either i) before the adversary received the responses from the honest users in Unmasking or ii) after such responses have been received, but where u𝑢u, v∈Q𝑣𝑄v\in Q.

    • •

      SIM programs the random oracle to set PRG​(bu)PRGsubscript𝑏𝑢\textrm{{PRG}}(b_{u}) for all u∈Q∖C𝑢𝑄𝐶u\in Q\setminus C to

      PRG​(bu)←𝒚u−𝒘u−∑v∈Fu∖QPRG​(su,v)←PRGsubscript𝑏𝑢subscript𝒚𝑢subscript𝒘𝑢subscript𝑣subscript𝐹𝑢𝑄PRGsubscript𝑠𝑢𝑣\textrm{{PRG}}(b_{u})\leftarrow\bm{y}_{u}-\bm{w}_{u}-\sum_{v\in F_{u}\setminus Q}\textrm{{PRG}}(s_{u,v})

      where {𝒘u}u∈Q∖Csubscriptsubscript𝒘𝑢𝑢𝑄𝐶\{\bm{w}_{u}\}_{u\in Q\setminus C} are chosen uniformly at random, subject to ∑u∈Q∖C𝒘u=∑u∈Q∖C𝚫~usubscript𝑢𝑄𝐶subscript𝒘𝑢subscript𝑢𝑄𝐶subscript~𝚫𝑢\sum_{u\in Q\setminus C}\bm{w}_{u}=\sum_{u\in Q\setminus C}\tilde{\bm{\Delta}}_{u} which is obtained by SIM via querying the functionality IDEAL for the set Q∖C𝑄𝐶Q\setminus C in Unmasking, v∈Fu𝑣subscript𝐹𝑢v\in F_{u} iff MCsubscript𝑀𝐶M_{C} delivered a ciphertext to u𝑢u from v𝑣v in ShareKeys. For all u∉Q∖C𝑢𝑄𝐶u\notin Q\setminus C, SIM sets PRG​(bu)PRGsubscript𝑏𝑢\textrm{{PRG}}(b_{u}) arbitrarily.

    Note: This hybrid does not make use of the honest parties’ 𝚫U∖Csubscript𝚫𝑈𝐶\bm{\Delta}_{U\setminus C}, which implies the security of SecAgg against malicious adversaries.

  4. Hyb4

    This hybrid is defined exactly as the previous one, except that SIM additionally aborts if MCsubscript𝑀𝐶M_{C} queries the random oracle for noise on input gu,ksubscript𝑔𝑢𝑘g_{u,k} for some honest user u𝑢u (i.e., the value sampled by SIM on behalf of u𝑢u in Setup) and either i) before the adversary received the responses from the honest users in Unmasking, or ii) after such responses have been received, but u∉Q𝑢𝑄u\notin Q, or iii) after such responses have been received and u∈Q𝑢𝑄u\in Q, but k<|U∖Q|+1𝑘𝑈𝑄1k<\lvert U\setminus Q\rvert+1.

    This hybrid is indistinguishable from the previous one because SIM will abort due to this new condition only if MCsubscript𝑀𝐶M_{C} is able to guess one of the gu,ksubscript𝑔𝑢𝑘g_{u,k}, which can only happen with negligible probability (as they are chosen from the exponentially large domain 𝔽𝔽\mathbb{F}). To see why the view of MCsubscript𝑀𝐶M_{C} does not depend on gu,ksubscript𝑔𝑢𝑘g_{u,k}, we can analyze which of the view’s components depend on any of those gu,ksubscript𝑔𝑢𝑘g_{u,k}. In case i), MCsubscript𝑀𝐶M_{C} only receives from SIM at most |C∩U|𝐶𝑈\lvert C\cap U\rvert shares of gu,ksubscript𝑔𝑢𝑘g_{u,k} (sent by u𝑢u in ShareKeys, one for each of the corrupt clients). However, since |C∩U|<t𝐶𝑈𝑡\lvert C\cap U\rvert<t, the distribution of any such shares is independent of gu,ksubscript𝑔𝑢𝑘g_{u,k} (because of the properties of secret sharing). In case ii), if u∉Q𝑢𝑄u\notin Q, the honest user u𝑢u would abort in ConsistencyCheck and do not join Unmasking. No other honest user would send to the server any share of gu,ksubscript𝑔𝑢𝑘g_{u,k} in ExcessiveNoiseRemoval, either. Thus SIM does not send have to send any to MCsubscript𝑀𝐶M_{C}. Even in case iii), the view of MCsubscript𝑀𝐶M_{C} is still independent of gu,ksubscript𝑔𝑢𝑘g_{u,k} for k<|U∖Q|+1𝑘𝑈𝑄1k<\lvert U\setminus Q\rvert+1: neither would the honest user u𝑢u send such gu,ksubscript𝑔𝑢𝑘g_{u,k} to the server in Unmasking, nor would any honest user send the shares of any of them to the server in ExcessiveNoiseRemoval.

  5. Hyb5

    This hybrid is defined exactly as the previous one, with the only difference being that SIM now does not receive the inputs of the honest parties, but instead, uses the {gu,k}u∈Q∖C,|U∖(Q∖C))|+1−|∩U|≤k≤T\{g_{u,k}\}_{u\in Q\setminus C,\lvert U\setminus(Q\setminus C))\rvert+1-\lvert\cap U\rvert\leq k\leq T} that are already queried from Ideal in Unmasking (see Hyb3) to send to or share with MCsubscript𝑀𝐶M_{C}.666Note that |U∖(Q∖C))|+1−|C∩U|\lvert U\setminus(Q\setminus C))\rvert+1-\lvert C\cap U\rvert (and thus, Ideal) is well-defined as i) it is always no smaller than 111 given that |Q∖C|≤|U|−|C∩U|𝑄𝐶𝑈𝐶𝑈\lvert Q\setminus C\rvert\leq\lvert U\rvert-\lvert C\cap U\rvert, and (ii) it can be larger than T𝑇T, which makes the received {𝒏u,k}subscript𝒏𝑢𝑘\{\bm{n}_{u,k}\} an empty set. More in detail, for all u∈Q∖C𝑢𝑄𝐶u\in Q\setminus C, SIM substitutes its gu,ksubscript𝑔𝑢𝑘g_{u,k} for 1≤k≤|U∖Q|1𝑘𝑈𝑄1\leq k\leq\lvert U\setminus Q\rvert with the corresponding one queried from Ideal, while setting those for |U∖Q|+1≤k≤T𝑈𝑄1𝑘𝑇\lvert U\setminus Q\rvert+1\leq k\leq T with uniformly random values, during both ShareKeys and Unmasking.

    Note that this is always feasible for SIM as i) Ideal will not abort (by construction |Q|≤t𝑄𝑡\lvert Q\rvert\leq t and thus |Q∖C|≤t−|C∩U|\lvert Q\setminus C\lvert\leq t-\lvert C\cap U\rvert), and ii) |U∖(Q∖C)|+1−|C∩U|≤|U∖Q|+1𝑈𝑄𝐶1𝐶𝑈𝑈𝑄1\lvert U\setminus(Q\setminus C)\rvert+1-\lvert C\cap U\rvert\leq\lvert U\setminus Q\rvert+1 always hold. It is easy to see that this change does not modify the view of the adversary, and therefore it is perfectly indistinguishable from the previous one. Moreover, this hybrid does not make use of the honest party’s gU∖Csubscript𝑔𝑈𝐶g_{U\setminus C} (and it does not use 𝚫U∖Csubscript𝚫𝑈𝐶\bm{\Delta}_{U\setminus C}, either, from Hyb3), and this concludes the proof.

∎

Given Lemma 1, we now proceed to the following theorem which provides an end-to-end malicious privacy guarantee of XNoise integrated with SecAgg.

Theorem 4 (Privacy against Malicious Adversaries):

For all η𝜂\eta, t𝑡t, U𝑈U, T𝑇T, TCsubscript𝑇𝐶T_{C}, C⊆U∪{S}𝐶𝑈𝑆C\subseteq U\cup\{S\}, 𝚫U∖Csubscript𝚫𝑈𝐶\bm{\Delta}_{U\setminus C} and gU∖Csubscript𝑔𝑈𝐶g_{U\setminus C}. If 2t>|U|+|C∩U|2t>\lvert U\rvert+\lvert C\cap U\lvert and TC≥|C∩U|subscript𝑇𝐶𝐶𝑈T_{C}\geq\lvert C\cap U\rvert, probabilistic polynomial-time (PPT) adversary, given its view of an execution of π𝜋\pi, cannot recover an aggregated update perturbed with noise less than the target level σ∗2superscriptsubscript𝜎2\sigma_{*}^{2} with non-negligible probability.

Appendix C Optimizing Number of Chunks for Pipelining

Suppose that m𝑚m is the number of chunks specified by the pipeline execution plan, τssubscript𝜏𝑠\tau_{s} is the predicted latency of executing a stage s𝑠s for any data chunk (note that each chunk has an equal size). Moreover, denote by a𝑎a the total number of stages in the distributed DP workflow, bs,csubscript𝑏𝑠𝑐b_{s,c}, fs,csubscript𝑓𝑠𝑐f_{s,c} the beginning and finishing time of stage s∈[a]𝑠delimited-[]𝑎s\in[a] for chunk c∈[m]𝑐delimited-[]𝑚c\in[m], respectively. To find the optimal number of chunks, m∗superscript𝑚m^{*}, Dordis solves the following optimization problem which minimizes the end-to-end latency τ𝜏\tau, which equates to the finishing time of the last stage for the last chunk, i.e., fa,msubscript𝑓𝑎𝑚f_{a,m}:

Note that constraint (4) is enforced as each chunk needs to sequentially go through the execution of all stages. Constraint (5) is enforced for achieving another two principles in the meantime: 1) each resource can be allocated at most one chunk to execute a stage at any time, and 2) allocating resource r𝑟r to execute stage s𝑠s for a chunk c𝑐c will be suspended, if there exists another chunk c′superscript𝑐′c^{\prime} which has not finished its execution of some previous stage q<s𝑞𝑠q<s that also uses the resource r𝑟r. This optimization problem can be solved by enumeration within a small range (e.g., m∈[20]𝑚delimited-[]20m\in[20]) provided that all τssubscript𝜏𝑠\tau_{s}’s have been profiled (section 4.2).

Appendix D Generic Programming Interface

Support for Diverse Distributed DP Algorithms.   As outlined in Section 5, Dordis offers developers the capability to implement customized distributed DP algorithms using the provided generic programming interface. To facilitate this, Table 4 presents the base classes that can be tailored to specific requirements.

The first base class, ProtocolServer, serves as a foundation for implementing various server-side workflows (as exemplified in Table 1). To streamline the development of computation logic, Dordis supplies established communication primitives based on Socket.IO (pyt, [n. d.])), which developers can employ to handle server-client interactions effectively. To specify the execution order and resource dependencies of different operations, Dordis further provides the set_graph_dict() method, allowing developers to annotate and aid Dordis in planning an optimized pipeline acceleration (see section 4.2).

For implementing the client-side workflow, developers can utilize the ProtocolClient base class, which can be customized to meet specific requirements. Additionally, Dordis provides the set_routine() method, enabling developers to specify which part of the client workflow is triggered by a specific server request.

In addition to facilitating high-level workflow construction, Dordis also equips developers with generic base classes to implement their own privacy and security primitives. These include differential privacy mechanisms (DPHandler), authenticated encryption schemes (AEHandler), key agreement protocols (KAHandler), pseudorandom number generators (PGHandler), and secret sharing algorithms (SSHandler). This empowers developers to easily integrate and experiment with diverse privacy and security building blocks.

Support for Diverse Applications.   Table 4 also demonstrates that Dordis offers developers the flexibility to extend the aggregation framework to power various privacy-sensitive applications beyond FL. This versatility allows for seamless integration into different use cases. To achieve this, developers can leverage the AppServer class by overriding the use_output() method, which specifies how the aggregated result is utilized by the server. Likewise, developers can instantiate their own AppClient and customize its behavior by overriding two methods. Firstly, the prepare_data() method can be modified to define how a client’s data is generated. Secondly, the use_output() method can be configured to determine how the aggregated result is consumed by the client. We have made Dordis open-source and warmly welcome contributions from the research community to further advance privacy-preserving data analytics research.

Appendix E Artifact Appendix

E.1. Abstract

We have made the artifact available in our GitHub repository’s main branch888At https://github.com/SamuelGong/Dordis. for reproducing the experimental results presented in the paper. Additionally, for long-term accessibility, we have also uploaded the artifact to a Zenodo repository.999At https://doi.org/10.5281/zenodo.10023704. The artifact comprises the source code of the Dordis, along with configuration files and Python scripts necessary to execute the experiments described in the paper. Further instructions on using the artifact can be found in the subsequent sections and in the README file of the repository.

E.2. Description & Requirements

E.2.1. How to access

The artifact is available at the above-mentioned repositories.

E.2.2. Hardware dependencies

Paper experiments were done in the following two modes:

  • •

    Simulation: When assessing the efficacy of noise enforcement (section 6.2), each experiment can be effectively simulated using a single node equipped with multiple GPUs for acceleration. This is because the metrics of interest, namely privacy budget consumption and final model accuracy, remain unaffected by system speed or network bandwidth. As a reference, our evaluation employed a machine with 8 NVIDIA Geforce RTX 2080 Ti GPUs.

  • •

    Cluster Deployment: During the evaluation of noise enforcement efficiency (section 6.3) and pipeline acceleration (section 6.4), the respective experiments necessitate an EC2 cluster setup. In this configuration, an r5.4xlarge instance serves as the server, while each client node is equipped with a c5.xlarge instance. This setup aims to replicate the computational capabilities of mobile devices. Additionally, the artifact includes scripts for simulating network heterogeneity by limiting the bandwidth of the client instances.

E.2.3. Software dependencies

The artifact requires an Anaconda environment with Python 3. While the specific Python packages used are listed in the ‘requirement.txt’ file of the GitHub repository, one can easily install them using provided scripts.

E.2.4. Benchmarks

As mentioned in section 6.1, the provided artifact utilizes publicly available machine learning datasets, namely CIFAR-10 (Krizhevsky et al., 2009), FEMNIST (Caldas et al., 2019), and Reddit (red, [n. d.]). Additionally, a variety of models are employed, including ResNet-18 (He et al., 2016), a customized CNN (Kairouz et al., 2021a; Agarwal et al., 2021), VGG-19 (Simonyan and Zisserman, 2014), and Albert (Lan et al., 2020). The artifact includes automated scripts that can be used to download and preprocess all the datasets.

E.3. Set-up

Installation and configuration steps required to prepare the artifact environment are described in the ‘Simulation’ and ‘Cluster Deployment’ section of the repository README file.

E.4. Evaluation workflow

E.4.1. Major Claims

As mentioned in section 6, the major experimental claims made in the paper are:

  • •

    C1: Our noise enforcement scheme, XNoise, guarantees the consistent achievement of the desired privacy level, even in the presence of client dropout, while maintaining the model utility. This claim is supported by the simulation experiment (E1) outlined in section 6.2, with the corresponding results presented in Figure 8, Table 2, and Figure 9.

  • •

    C2: The XNoise scheme introduces acceptable runtime overhead, with the network overhead being scalable with respect to the model’s expanding size. S This can be proven by the cluster experiment (E2) described in 6.3 whose results are reported in Figure 10 and Table 3.

  • •

    C3: The pipeline-parallel aggregation design employed by Dordis significantly boosts training speed, leading to a remarkable improvement of up to 2.4×\times in the training round time. This finding is supported by the cluster experiment (E3) discussed in section 6.4, and the corresponding results are depicted in Figure 10.

E.4.2. Experiments

The artifact includes a dedicated section in the repository’s README file titled ‘Reproducing Experimental Results’. This section provides a comprehensive guide on conducting the necessary experiments to replicate the main claims mentioned earlier. For every experiment, we meticulously document all the essential setup requirements, estimated costs and timeframes, a concise explanation of the procedure, the anticipated outcomes, and an explicit link to one of the aforementioned three claims.
